  <us-gaap:Revenues contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0005_STD_p6m_20090630_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">19558000000</us-gaap:Revenues>
  <us-gaap:ScheduleOfSubsequentEventsTextBlock contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0005_STD_p6m_20090630_0">&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note 13.&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Subsequent
Events:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In July 2009, we announced our intention
to redeem our November 2011, 7% $200 million debenture at par
value. Upon early extinguishment of this debenture, we expect to
record a loss of approximately $14 million.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We evaluated subsequent events through
August&amp;#160;5, 2009 and included all accounting and disclosure
requirements related to subsequent events in our financial
statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;

</us-gaap:ScheduleOfSubsequentEventsTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:SegmentReportingDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0005_STD_p6m_20090630_0">&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note 12.&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Segment
Reporting:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Effective January 2009, we began
implementing changes to our operating structure based on our
&lt;i&gt;Organizing For Growth&lt;/i&gt; initiative and Kraft Foods Europe
Reorganization. In line with our strategies, we are reorganizing
our European operations to function on a pan-European centralized
category management and value chain model, and we changed how we
work in Europe in two key ways:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;table style="BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellspacing="0"
cellpadding="0" width="100%" border="0"&gt;
&lt;tbody&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td width="5%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left" width="2%"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&amp;#8226;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" width="1%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left"&gt;
&lt;p align="left"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We
transitioned our European Biscuit, Chocolate, Coffee and Cheese
categories to fully integrated business units, further
strengthening our focus on these core categories. To ensure
decisions are made faster and closer to our customers and
consumers, each category is fully accountable for its financial
results, including marketing, manufacturing and R&amp;amp;D. Category
leadership, based in Zurich, Switzerland, reports to the Kraft
Foods Europe President. These business units now comprise the Kraft
Foods Europe segment.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/tbody&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;table style="BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellspacing="0"
cellpadding="0" width="100%" border="0"&gt;
&lt;tbody&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td width="5%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left" width="2%"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&amp;#8226;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" width="1%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left"&gt;
&lt;p align="left"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We aligned
the reporting of our Central Europe operations into our Kraft Foods
Developing Markets segment to help build critical scale in these
countries. We operate a country-led model in these
markets.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/tbody&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We manufacture and market packaged food
products, including snacks, beverages, cheese, convenient meals and
various packaged grocery products. We manage and report operating
results through three commercial units: Kraft Foods North America,
Kraft Foods Europe and Kraft Foods Developing Markets. We manage
the operations of Kraft Foods North America and Kraft Foods Europe
by product category, and we manage the operations of Kraft Foods
Developing Markets by geographic location. Our reportable segments
are U.S. Beverages, U.S. Cheese, U.S. Convenient Meals, U.S.
Grocery, U.S. Snacks, Canada&amp;#160;&amp;amp; North America Foodservice,
Kraft Foods Europe (formerly known as European Union) and Kraft
Foods Developing Markets.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font size=
"1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Management uses segment operating income
to evaluate segment performance and allocate resources. We believe
it is appropriate to disclose this measure to help investors
analyze segment performance and trends. Segment operating income
excludes unrealized gains and losses on hedging activities (which
are a component of cost of sales), certain components of our U.S.
pension plan cost (which is a component of cost of sales and
marketing, administration and research costs), general corporate
expenses (which are a component of marketing, administration and
research costs) and amortization of intangibles for all periods
presented. In 2009, we began excluding certain components of our
U.S. pension plan cost from segment operating income because we
centrally manage pension plan funding decisions and the
determination of discount rate, expected rate of return on plan
assets and other actuarial assumptions. Therefore, we allocate only
the service cost component of our U.S. pension plan expense to
segment operating income. We exclude the unrealized gains and
losses on hedging activities from segment operating income in order
to provide better transparency of our segment operating results.
Once realized, the gains and losses on hedging activities are
recorded within segment operating results. Furthermore, we
centrally manage interest and other expense, net. Accordingly, we
do not present these items by segment because they are excluded
from the segment profitability measure that management
reviews.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Segment data were:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;td valign="top" colspan="18"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Asset Impairment Charges &amp;#8211;&lt;/i&gt;
We recorded a $9 million asset impairment charge to write-off an
investment in Norway. The charge was recorded within asset
impairment and exit costs within the segment operating income of
Kraft Foods Europe.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Unrealized Gains on Hedging
Activities&lt;/i&gt; &amp;#8211; We recognized gains on the change in
unrealized hedging positions of $34 million for the three months
and $121 million for the six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2009, and
$78 million for the three months and $103 million for the six
months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2008.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Net revenues by consumer sector, which
includes &lt;i&gt;Kraft&lt;/i&gt; macaroni and cheese dinners in the Convenient
Meals sector and the separation of Canada&amp;#160;&amp;amp; N.A.
Foodservice, and Kraft Foods Europe and Kraft Foods Developing
Markets into sector components, were:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 1px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:SegmentReportingDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:SellingGeneralAndAdministrativeExpense contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0005_STD_p6m_20090630_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">4131000000</us-gaap:SellingGeneralAndAdministrativeExpense>
  <us-gaap:ShareBasedCompensation contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0005_STD_p6m_20090630_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">84000000</us-gaap:ShareBasedCompensation>
  <us-gaap:SignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0005_STD_p6m_20090630_0">&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note 1.&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Summary of
Significant Accounting Policies:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Basis of Presentation:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Our interim condensed consolidated
financial statements are unaudited. We prepared the condensed
consolidated financial statements following SEC rules for interim
reporting. As permitted under those rules, we have condensed or
omitted a number of footnotes or other financial information that
are normally required by accounting principles generally accepted
in the United States of America. It is management&amp;#8217;s opinion
that these financial statements include all normal and recurring
adjustments necessary for a fair presentation of our financial
position and operating results. Net revenues and net earnings for
any interim period are not necessarily indicative of future or
annual results.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;You should read these statements in
conjunction with our consolidated financial statements and related
notes in our Form 10-K for the year ended December&amp;#160;31,
2008.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Inventories:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Effective January&amp;#160;1, 2009, we
changed our method of valuing our U.S. inventories to the average
cost method. In prior years, principally all U.S. inventories were
valued using the last-in, first-out (&amp;#8220;LIFO&amp;#8221;) method.
With this change, we value all of our inventories using the average
cost method. We used the LIFO method to determine the cost of 35%
of inventories at December&amp;#160;31, 2008. We believe that the
average cost method of accounting for U.S. inventories is
preferable and will improve financial reporting by better matching
revenues and expenses to current costs, by better aligning our
external reporting with our competitors, and by aligning our
external reporting with our tax basis of accounting. We restated
prior years&amp;#8217; financial statements to conform to the change in
accounting policy.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;The following line items within the
statements of earnings were affected by the change in accounting
policy:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-LEFT: 1em; TEXT-INDENT: -1em"&gt;&lt;font face=

"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Deferred income tax asset&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-LEFT: 1em; TEXT-INDENT: -1em"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Retained earnings&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" align="right"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;13,345&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" align="right"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;13,440&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" align="right"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;95&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" colspan="15"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;As a result of the accounting change,
retained earnings as of January&amp;#160;1, 2008, increased from
$12,209 million, as computed using the LIFO method, to $12,321
million using the average cost method.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;There was no impact to net cash provided
by operating activities as a result of this change in accounting
policy.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Excise Taxes:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 1px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Effective January&amp;#160;1, 2009, we
changed our classification of certain excise taxes to a net
presentation within cost of sales. In prior years, excise taxes
were classified gross within net revenues and cost of sales. With
this change, we report all of our excise and similar taxes using
the net presentation method. We made this change to better align
our net revenues between various countries and to provide better
clarity to net revenues and margins. We restated prior years&amp;#8217;
financial statements to conform to this change. As a result, we
removed $66 million for the three months and $122 million for the
six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2008 from net revenues, and netted
the amounts within cost of sales. If we had not made this change,
for the three months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2009, net revenues of
$10,162 million would have been $10,216 million, and cost of sales
of $6,497 million would have been $6,551 million; and for the six
months ended June 30, 2009, net revenues of $19,558 million would
have been $19,654 million, and cost of sales of $12,628 million
would have been $12,724 million. This change did not have a
material impact on our net revenues or cost of sales.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;!-- 6 Last_Row * DO NOT REMOVE OR EDIT --&gt;&lt;/tbody&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font size=
"1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;!--##PBStart##--&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Reclassification:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We changed our cost assignment
methodology for headquarter functional costs across our operating
structure. As a result, we reclassified $48 million for the three
months and $95 million for the six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2008
from marketing, administration and research costs to cost of sales.
This change did not have an impact on net earnings.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Financial Instruments:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Interest rate cash flow and fair
value hedges &amp;#8211;&lt;/i&gt; We manage interest rate volatility by
modifying the repricing or maturity characteristics of certain
liabilities so that the net interest margin is not, on a material
basis, adversely affected by movements in interest rates. As a
result of interest rate fluctuations, hedged fixed-rate liabilities
appreciate or depreciate in market value. The effect of this
unrealized appreciation or depreciation is expected to be
substantially offset by our gains or losses on the derivative
instruments that are linked to these hedged liabilities.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We use derivative instruments, including
interest rate swaps that have indices related to the pricing of
specific liabilities as part of our interest rate risk management
strategy. As a matter of policy, we do not use highly leveraged
derivative instruments for interest rate risk management. Under the
interest rate swap contracts, we agree with other parties to
exchange, at specified intervals, the difference between fixed-rate
and floating-rate interest amounts, which is calculated based on an
agreed-upon notional amount. We use interest rate swaps to hedge
the variability of interest payment cash flows on a portion of our
future debt obligations. We also use interest rate swaps to
economically convert a portion of our nonprepayable fixed-rate debt
into variable rate debt. Substantially all of these derivative
instruments are highly effective and qualify for hedge accounting
treatment under Statement of Financial Accounting Standards
(&amp;#8220;SFAS&amp;#8221;) No.&amp;#160;133, &lt;i&gt;Accounting for Derivative
Instruments and Hedging Activities&lt;/i&gt;.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;For those derivative instruments that
are highly effective and qualify for hedge accounting treatment
under SFAS No.&amp;#160;133, we either record the impacts in current
period earnings or defer the effective portion of unrealized gains
and losses as a component of accumulated other comprehensive
earnings / (losses), depending on whether the hedging relationship
satisfies the criteria for a fair value or cash flow hedge. For
fair value hedges, we record both (i)&amp;#160;the gains or losses on
interest rate swaps and (ii)&amp;#160;the corresponding changes in fair
value of the hedged long-term debt directly as a component of
interest and other expense, net. For cash flow hedges, we recognize
the deferred portion as a component of interest and other expense,
net when we incur the interest expense. The ineffective portion is
directly recorded as a component of interest and other expense,
net. For the derivative instruments that we consider economic
hedges but do not designate for hedge accounting treatment under
SFAS No.&amp;#160;133, we recognize gains and losses directly as a
component of interest and other expense, net.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Refer to our Form 10-K for the year
ended December&amp;#160;31, 2008 for information on all other types of
financial instruments we use to hedge exposures.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;New Accounting
Pronouncements:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In September 2006, the Financial
Accounting Standards Board (&amp;#8220;FASB&amp;#8221;) issued SFAS
No.&amp;#160;157, &lt;i&gt;Fair Value Measurements&lt;/i&gt;, as amended in
February 2008 by FASB Staff Position (&amp;#8220;FSP&amp;#8221;) FAS 157-2,
&lt;i&gt;Effective Date of FASB Statement No.&amp;#160;157&lt;/i&gt;. SFAS
No.&amp;#160;157 defines fair value, establishes a framework for
measuring fair value and expands disclosures about fair value
measurements. FSP FAS 157-2 deferred the effective date of SFAS
No.&amp;#160;157 for all nonfinancial assets and liabilities, except
those items recognized or disclosed at fair value on an annual or
more frequently recurring basis, until January&amp;#160;1, 2009. As
such, we partially adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&amp;#160;157
effective January&amp;#160;1, 2008. The partial adoption of this
statement did not have a material impact on our financial
statements. We adopted the remaining provisions of SFAS
No.&amp;#160;157 effective January&amp;#160;1, 2009. This adoption impacts
the way that we calculate fair value for our annual impairment
review of goodwill and non-amortizable intangible assets, and when
conditions exist that require us to calculate the fair value of
long-lived assets; however, this adoption did not have a material
impact on our financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In December 2007, the FASB issued SFAS
No.&amp;#160;141(R), &lt;i&gt;Business Combinations&lt;/i&gt;. Effective
January&amp;#160;1, 2009, we adopted the provisions of SFAS
No.&amp;#160;141(R), which change the way companies account for
business combinations. This statement requires the acquiring entity
in a business combination to recognize all assets acquired and
liabilities assumed in the transaction; establishes the
acquisition-date fair value as the measurement objective for all
assets acquired and liabilities assumed; and requires the acquirer
to disclose all information needed by investors to understand the
nature and financial effect of the business combination. The
adoption of this statement did not have a material impact on our
financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;!--##PBStart##--&gt;
&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center"
border="0"&gt;&lt;!-- 5 First_Row * DO NOT REMOVE OR EDIT --&gt;

&lt;td width="6%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="5%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td width="49%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="5%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="5%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="5%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td width="16%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="5%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" colspan="13"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In December 2007, the FASB also issued
SFAS No.&amp;#160;160, &lt;i&gt;Noncontrolling Interests in Consolidated
Financial Statements&amp;#8211;an amendment of Accounting Research
Bulletin No.&amp;#160;51&lt;/i&gt;. We adopted the provisions of SFAS
No.&amp;#160;160 effective January&amp;#160;1, 2009. This statement
required us to classify noncontrolling interests in subsidiaries as
a separate component of equity instead of within accrued
liabilities. Additionally, transactions between an entity and
noncontrolling interests must be treated as equity transactions.
Therefore, they no longer are removed from net income, but rather
are accounted for as equity. The adoption of this statement did not
have a material impact on our financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In March 2008, the FASB issued SFAS
No.&amp;#160;161, &lt;i&gt;Disclosures about Derivative Instruments and
Hedging Activities.&lt;/i&gt; We adopted the provisions of SFAS
No.&amp;#160;161 effective January&amp;#160;1, 2009. This statement
requires enhanced disclosures about (i)&amp;#160;how and why we use
derivative instruments, (ii)&amp;#160;how we account for derivative
instruments and related hedged items under SFAS No.&amp;#160;133, and
(iii)&amp;#160;how derivative instruments and related hedged items
affect our financial results. The adoption of this statement did
not have an impact on our financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In June 2008, the FASB issued FSP
Emerging Issues Task Force (&amp;#8220;EITF&amp;#8221;) 03-6-1,
&lt;i&gt;Determining Whether Instruments Granted in Share-Based Payment
Transactions are Participating Securities&lt;/i&gt;. We adopted the
provisions of FSP EITF 03-6-1 effective January&amp;#160;1, 2009. FSP
EITF 03-6-1 considers unvested share-based payment awards with the
right to receive nonforfeitable dividends or their equivalents
participating securities that should be included in the calculation
of EPS under the two-class method. Accordingly, due to the adoption
of FSP EITF 03-6-1, our restricted and deferred stock awards are
now considered participating units in our calculation of EPS. The
adoption of this statement did not have a material impact on our
financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In December 2008, the FASB issued FSP
FAS No.&amp;#160;132(R)-1, &lt;i&gt;Employers&amp;#8217; Disclosures about
Postretirement Benefit Plan Assets&lt;/i&gt;, which is effective for
fiscal years ending after December&amp;#160;15, 2009. FSP FAS
No.&amp;#160;132(R)-1 provides guidance on an employer&amp;#8217;s
disclosures about plan assets of a defined benefit pension or other
postretirement plan. We do not expect the adoption of this
statement to have a material impact on our financial
statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In May 2009, the FASB issued SFAS
No.&amp;#160;165, &lt;i&gt;Subsequent Events&lt;/i&gt;. SFAS No.&amp;#160;165 requires
management to evaluate subsequent events through the date the
financial statements are either issued or available to be issued,
depending on the company&amp;#8217;s expectation of whether it will
widely distribute its financial statements to its shareholders and
other financial statement users. Companies are required to disclose
the date through which subsequent events have been evaluated. We
adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&amp;#160;165 effective June&amp;#160;30,
2009.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/tbody&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;

</us-gaap:SignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:StockIssuedDuringPeriodValueStockOptionsExercised contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0005_STD_p6m_20090630_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">99000000</us-gaap:StockIssuedDuringPeriodValueStockOptionsExercised>
  <kft:ProfitLoss contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0005_STD_p6m_20090630_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">1491000000</kft:ProfitLoss>
  <kft:NetIncomeLossAttributableToNoncontrollingInterest contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0005_STD_p6m_20090630_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">4000000</kft:NetIncomeLossAttributableToNoncontrollingInterest>
  <kft:IncomeLossFromContinuingOperationsIncludingPortionAttributableToNoncontrollingInterest contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0005_STD_p6m_20090630_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">1491000000</kft:IncomeLossFromContinuingOperationsIncludingPortionAttributableToNoncontrollingInterest>
  <kft:ComprehensiveIncomeNetOfTaxIncludingPortionAttributableToNoncontrollingInterest contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0005_STD_p6m_20090630_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6" id="fnid_435388_7007_17">2784000000</kft:ComprehensiveIncomeNetOfTaxIncludingPortionAttributableToNoncontrollingInterest>
  <kft:EarningsPerShareTextBlock contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0005_STD_p6m_20090630_0">&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note 11.&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Earnings Per
Share:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Basic and diluted EPS were calculated
using the following:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We exclude antidilutive Kraft Foods
stock options from our calculation of weighted-average shares for
diluted EPS. We excluded 23.8&amp;#160;million antidilutive options for
the three and six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2009, and we excluded
0.6&amp;#160;million antidilutive options for the three months and
11.6&amp;#160;million antidilutive options for the six months ended
June&amp;#160;30, 2008.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

    <xbrll:footnote xlink:label="footnote_435374" xlink:role="http://www.xbrl.org/2003/role/footnote" xlink:type="resource" xml:lang="en-US">Total comprehensive earnings / (losses) were $2,274 million for the quarter ended June 30, 2009, $1,017 million for the quarter ended June 30, 2008 and $2,012 million for the six months ended June 30, 2008. Comprehensive earnings / (losses) attributable to Kraft Foods were $2,250 million for the quarter ended June 30, 2009, $2,758 million for the six months ended June 30, 2009, $1,013 million for the quarter ended June 30, 2008 and $2,005 million for the six months ended June 30, 2008.</xbrll:footnote>

      <LabelColumn>false</LabelColumn>
      <Id>1</Id>

      </Labels>

      <hasScenarios>false</hasScenarios>
      <Segments />
      <Scenarios />
      <Units>
        <Unit>
          <UnitID>USD</UnitID>
          <UnitType>Standard</UnitType>
          <StandardMeasure>
            <MeasureSchema>http://www.xbrl.org/2003/iso4217</MeasureSchema>
            <MeasureValue>USD</MeasureValue>
            <MeasureNamespace>iso4217</MeasureNamespace>
          </StandardMeasure>
          <Scale>0</Scale>
        </Unit>
        <Unit>
          <UnitID>USDperShareItemType</UnitID>

          <NonNumbericText>&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note 1.&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Summary of
Significant Accounting Policies:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Basis of Presentation:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Our interim condensed consolidated
financial statements are unaudited. We prepared the condensed
consolidated financial statements following SEC rules for interim
reporting. As permitted under those rules, we have condensed or
omitted a number of footnotes or other financial information that
are normally required by accounting principles generally accepted
in the United States of America. It is management&amp;#8217;s opinion
that these financial statements include all normal and recurring
adjustments necessary for a fair presentation of our financial
position and operating results. Net revenues and net earnings for
any interim period are not necessarily indicative of future or
annual results.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;You should read these statements in
conjunction with our consolidated financial statements and related
notes in our Form 10-K for the year ended December&amp;#160;31,
2008.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Inventories:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Effective January&amp;#160;1, 2009, we
changed our method of valuing our U.S. inventories to the average
cost method. In prior years, principally all U.S. inventories were
valued using the last-in, first-out (&amp;#8220;LIFO&amp;#8221;) method.
With this change, we value all of our inventories using the average
cost method. We used the LIFO method to determine the cost of 35%
of inventories at December&amp;#160;31, 2008. We believe that the
average cost method of accounting for U.S. inventories is
preferable and will improve financial reporting by better matching
revenues and expenses to current costs, by better aligning our
external reporting with our competitors, and by aligning our
external reporting with our tax basis of accounting. We restated
prior years&amp;#8217; financial statements to conform to the change in
accounting policy.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;The following line items within the
statements of earnings were affected by the change in accounting
policy:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center"
border="0"&gt;&lt;!-- 5 First_Row * DO NOT REMOVE OR EDIT --&gt;
&lt;tbody&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td width="6%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="2%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td width="50%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="2%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="2%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="2%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="2%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td width="11%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;

&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=

&lt;td valign="top"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-LEFT: 1em; TEXT-INDENT: -1em"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Deferred income tax asset&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=

&lt;td valign="bottom" align="right"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;861&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=

&lt;td valign="bottom" align="right"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;804&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" align="right"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;57&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-LEFT: 1em; TEXT-INDENT: -1em"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Retained earnings&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" align="right"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;13,345&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" align="right"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;13,440&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" align="right"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;95&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" colspan="15"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;As a result of the accounting change,
retained earnings as of January&amp;#160;1, 2008, increased from
$12,209 million, as computed using the LIFO method, to $12,321
million using the average cost method.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;There was no impact to net cash provided
by operating activities as a result of this change in accounting
policy.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Excise Taxes:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 1px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Effective January&amp;#160;1, 2009, we
changed our classification of certain excise taxes to a net
presentation within cost of sales. In prior years, excise taxes
were classified gross within net revenues and cost of sales. With
this change, we report all of our excise and similar taxes using
the net presentation method. We made this change to better align
our net revenues between various countries and to provide better
clarity to net revenues and margins. We restated prior years&amp;#8217;
financial statements to conform to this change. As a result, we
removed $66 million for the three months and $122 million for the
six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2008 from net revenues, and netted
the amounts within cost of sales. If we had not made this change,
for the three months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2009, net revenues of
$10,162 million would have been $10,216 million, and cost of sales
of $6,497 million would have been $6,551 million; and for the six
months ended June 30, 2009, net revenues of $19,558 million would
have been $19,654 million, and cost of sales of $12,628 million
would have been $12,724 million. This change did not have a
material impact on our net revenues or cost of sales.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;!-- 6 Last_Row * DO NOT REMOVE OR EDIT --&gt;&lt;/tbody&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font size=
"1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;!--##PBStart##--&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Reclassification:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We changed our cost assignment
methodology for headquarter functional costs across our operating
structure. As a result, we reclassified $48 million for the three
months and $95 million for the six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2008
from marketing, administration and research costs to cost of sales.
This change did not have an impact on net earnings.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Financial Instruments:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Interest rate cash flow and fair
value hedges &amp;#8211;&lt;/i&gt; We manage interest rate volatility by
modifying the repricing or maturity characteristics of certain
liabilities so that the net interest margin is not, on a material
basis, adversely affected by movements in interest rates. As a
result of interest rate fluctuations, hedged fixed-rate liabilities
appreciate or depreciate in market value. The effect of this
unrealized appreciation or depreciation is expected to be
substantially offset by our gains or losses on the derivative
instruments that are linked to these hedged liabilities.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We use derivative instruments, including
interest rate swaps that have indices related to the pricing of
specific liabilities as part of our interest rate risk management
strategy. As a matter of policy, we do not use highly leveraged
derivative instruments for interest rate risk management. Under the
interest rate swap contracts, we agree with other parties to
exchange, at specified intervals, the difference between fixed-rate
and floating-rate interest amounts, which is calculated based on an
agreed-upon notional amount. We use interest rate swaps to hedge
the variability of interest payment cash flows on a portion of our
future debt obligations. We also use interest rate swaps to
economically convert a portion of our nonprepayable fixed-rate debt
into variable rate debt. Substantially all of these derivative
instruments are highly effective and qualify for hedge accounting
treatment under Statement of Financial Accounting Standards
(&amp;#8220;SFAS&amp;#8221;) No.&amp;#160;133, &lt;i&gt;Accounting for Derivative
Instruments and Hedging Activities&lt;/i&gt;.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;For those derivative instruments that
are highly effective and qualify for hedge accounting treatment
under SFAS No.&amp;#160;133, we either record the impacts in current
period earnings or defer the effective portion of unrealized gains
and losses as a component of accumulated other comprehensive
earnings / (losses), depending on whether the hedging relationship
satisfies the criteria for a fair value or cash flow hedge. For
fair value hedges, we record both (i)&amp;#160;the gains or losses on
interest rate swaps and (ii)&amp;#160;the corresponding changes in fair
value of the hedged long-term debt directly as a component of
interest and other expense, net. For cash flow hedges, we recognize
the deferred portion as a component of interest and other expense,
net when we incur the interest expense. The ineffective portion is
directly recorded as a component of interest and other expense,
net. For the derivative instruments that we consider economic
hedges but do not designate for hedge accounting treatment under
SFAS No.&amp;#160;133, we recognize gains and losses directly as a
component of interest and other expense, net.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Refer to our Form 10-K for the year
ended December&amp;#160;31, 2008 for information on all other types of
financial instruments we use to hedge exposures.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;New Accounting
Pronouncements:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In September 2006, the Financial
Accounting Standards Board (&amp;#8220;FASB&amp;#8221;) issued SFAS
No.&amp;#160;157, &lt;i&gt;Fair Value Measurements&lt;/i&gt;, as amended in
February 2008 by FASB Staff Position (&amp;#8220;FSP&amp;#8221;) FAS 157-2,
&lt;i&gt;Effective Date of FASB Statement No.&amp;#160;157&lt;/i&gt;. SFAS
No.&amp;#160;157 defines fair value, establishes a framework for
measuring fair value and expands disclosures about fair value
measurements. FSP FAS 157-2 deferred the effective date of SFAS
No.&amp;#160;157 for all nonfinancial assets and liabilities, except
those items recognized or disclosed at fair value on an annual or
more frequently recurring basis, until January&amp;#160;1, 2009. As
such, we partially adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&amp;#160;157
effective January&amp;#160;1, 2008. The partial adoption of this
statement did not have a material impact on our financial
statements. We adopted the remaining provisions of SFAS
No.&amp;#160;157 effective January&amp;#160;1, 2009. This adoption impacts
the way that we calculate fair value for our annual impairment
review of goodwill and non-amortizable intangible assets, and when
conditions exist that require us to calculate the fair value of
long-lived assets; however, this adoption did not have a material
impact on our financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In December 2007, the FASB issued SFAS
No.&amp;#160;141(R), &lt;i&gt;Business Combinations&lt;/i&gt;. Effective
January&amp;#160;1, 2009, we adopted the provisions of SFAS
No.&amp;#160;141(R), which change the way companies account for
business combinations. This statement requires the acquiring entity
in a business combination to recognize all assets acquired and
liabilities assumed in the transaction; establishes the
acquisition-date fair value as the measurement objective for all
assets acquired and liabilities assumed; and requires the acquirer
to disclose all information needed by investors to understand the
nature and financial effect of the business combination. The
adoption of this statement did not have a material impact on our
financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;!--##PBStart##--&gt;
&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center"
border="0"&gt;&lt;!-- 5 First_Row * DO NOT REMOVE OR EDIT --&gt;
&lt;tbody&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td width="6%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="5%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td width="49%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="5%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="5%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="5%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td width="16%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="5%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" colspan="13"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In December 2007, the FASB also issued
SFAS No.&amp;#160;160, &lt;i&gt;Noncontrolling Interests in Consolidated
Financial Statements&amp;#8211;an amendment of Accounting Research
Bulletin No.&amp;#160;51&lt;/i&gt;. We adopted the provisions of SFAS
No.&amp;#160;160 effective January&amp;#160;1, 2009. This statement
required us to classify noncontrolling interests in subsidiaries as
a separate component of equity instead of within accrued
liabilities. Additionally, transactions between an entity and
noncontrolling interests must be treated as equity transactions.
Therefore, they no longer are removed from net income, but rather
are accounted for as equity. The adoption of this statement did not
have a material impact on our financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In March 2008, the FASB issued SFAS
No.&amp;#160;161, &lt;i&gt;Disclosures about Derivative Instruments and
Hedging Activities.&lt;/i&gt; We adopted the provisions of SFAS
No.&amp;#160;161 effective January&amp;#160;1, 2009. This statement
requires enhanced disclosures about (i)&amp;#160;how and why we use
derivative instruments, (ii)&amp;#160;how we account for derivative
instruments and related hedged items under SFAS No.&amp;#160;133, and
(iii)&amp;#160;how derivative instruments and related hedged items
affect our financial results. The adoption of this statement did
not have an impact on our financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In June 2008, the FASB issued FSP
Emerging Issues Task Force (&amp;#8220;EITF&amp;#8221;) 03-6-1,
&lt;i&gt;Determining Whether Instruments Granted in Share-Based Payment
Transactions are Participating Securities&lt;/i&gt;. We adopted the
provisions of FSP EITF 03-6-1 effective January&amp;#160;1, 2009. FSP
EITF 03-6-1 considers unvested share-based payment awards with the
right to receive nonforfeitable dividends or their equivalents
participating securities that should be included in the calculation
of EPS under the two-class method. Accordingly, due to the adoption
of FSP EITF 03-6-1, our restricted and deferred stock awards are
now considered participating units in our calculation of EPS. The
adoption of this statement did not have a material impact on our
financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In December 2008, the FASB issued FSP
FAS No.&amp;#160;132(R)-1, &lt;i&gt;Employers&amp;#8217; Disclosures about
Postretirement Benefit Plan Assets&lt;/i&gt;, which is effective for
fiscal years ending after December&amp;#160;15, 2009. FSP FAS
No.&amp;#160;132(R)-1 provides guidance on an employer&amp;#8217;s
disclosures about plan assets of a defined benefit pension or other
postretirement plan. We do not expect the adoption of this
statement to have a material impact on our financial
statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In May 2009, the FASB issued SFAS
No.&amp;#160;165, &lt;i&gt;Subsequent Events&lt;/i&gt;. SFAS No.&amp;#160;165 requires
management to evaluate subsequent events through the date the
financial statements are either issued or available to be issued,
depending on the company&amp;#8217;s expectation of whether it will
widely distribute its financial statements to its shareholders and
other financial statement users. Companies are required to disclose
the date through which subsequent events have been evaluated. We
adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&amp;#160;165 effective June&amp;#160;30,
2009.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/tbody&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;

</NonNumbericText>

financial statements are unaudited. We</NonNumericTextHeader>

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note
2.&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Divestitures:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Post Cereals
Split-off:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;On August&amp;#160;4, 2008, we completed the
split-off of the &lt;i&gt;Post&lt;/i&gt; cereals business into Ralcorp
Holdings, Inc., after an exchange with our shareholders.
Accordingly, we restated prior period results to reflect the
results of the &lt;i&gt;Post&lt;/i&gt; cereals business as discontinued
operations on the condensed consolidated statement of earnings.
Refer to our Form 10-K for the year ended December&amp;#160;31, 2008
for further details of this transaction.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;

"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Summary results of operations for the
&lt;i&gt;Post&lt;/i&gt; cereals business for the three and six months ended
June&amp;#160;30, 2008 were as follows:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

received $6 million in proceeds and recorded pre-tax losses of $17
million on the divestitures of a juice operation in Brazil and a
plant in Spain.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note
3.&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Inventories:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Inventories at June&amp;#160;30, 2009 and
December&amp;#160;31, 2008 were:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"1"&gt;(1)&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;This segment was formerly known as
European Union.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" colspan="13"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;As discussed in Note 12, &lt;i&gt;Segment
Reporting&lt;/i&gt;, we implemented changes to our operating structure in
2009. As a result of these changes, we aligned the reporting of our
Central Europe operations into our Kraft Foods Developing Markets
segment and moved $1,534 million of goodwill from Kraft Foods
Europe to Kraft Foods Developing Markets as of January&amp;#160;1,
2009. We restated prior period segment results in a consistent
manner.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;

&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 1px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Non-amortizable intangible assets
consist substantially of brand names purchased through our
acquisitions of Nabisco Holdings Corp., the global &lt;i&gt;LU&lt;/i&gt;
biscuit business of Groupe Danone S.A. and the Spanish and
Portuguese operations of United Biscuits. Amortizable intangible
assets consist primarily of trademark licenses, customer-related
intangibles and non-compete agreements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Amortization expense for intangible
assets was $3 million for the three months and $9 million for the
six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2009. We currently estimate
amortization expense for each of the next five years to be
approximately $20 million or less.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

          <NonNumbericText>&lt;div&gt;
&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center"
border="0"&gt;
&lt;tbody&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" colspan="17"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note 5.&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Restructuring
Costs:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;2004 &amp;#8211; 2008 Restructuring
Program:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In 2008, we completed our five-year
restructuring program (the &amp;#8220;Restructuring Program&amp;#8221;).
The Restructuring Program&amp;#8217;s objectives were to leverage our
global scale, realign and lower our cost structure, and optimize
capacity. As part of the Restructuring Program, we:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style=
"MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; MARGIN-LEFT: 4em; TEXT-INDENT: -1.5em"&gt;
&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#8226;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;incurred $3.0
billion in pre-tax charges reflecting asset disposals, severance
and implementation costs;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style=
"MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; MARGIN-LEFT: 4em; TEXT-INDENT: -1.5em"&gt;
&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#8226;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;announced the
closure of 35 facilities and announced the elimination of
approximately 18,800 positions; and&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style=
"MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; MARGIN-LEFT: 4em; TEXT-INDENT: -1.5em"&gt;
&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#8226;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;will use cash to pay
for $2.0 billion of the $3.0 billion in charges.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In the second quarter of 2009, we sold a
plant in Spain that we previously announced for closure under our
Restructuring Program. Accordingly, we reversed $35 million in
Restructuring Program charges during the second quarter of 2009,
primarily related to severance, and recorded a $17 million loss on
the divestiture of the plant. The reversal of the Restructuring
Program costs, which affected the segment operating income of the
Kraft Foods Europe segment, was recorded within asset impairment
and exit costs. Since the inception of the Restructuring Program,
we have paid cash for $1.6 billion of the $3.0 billion in charges,
including $80 million paid in the first six months of 2009. At
June&amp;#160;30, 2009, we had an accrual of $399 million, and we had
eliminated approximately 16,000 positions under the Restructuring
Program.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Restructuring liability activity for the
six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2009 was:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 1px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1px solid" valign="bottom" align=
"middle" colspan="2"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Severance&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1px solid" valign="bottom" align=
"middle" colspan="2"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=

&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 1px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Our 2009 activity was related to the
aforementioned reversal of $35 million and cash outflows on prior
year Restructuring Program charges. Our prior year severance
charges included the cost of benefits received by terminated
employees. Other prior year costs related primarily to the
renegotiation of supplier contract costs, workforce reductions
associated with facility closings and the termination of leasing
agreements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;td valign="top" colspan="11"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note 7.&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Stock
Plans:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;At our annual meeting of shareholders
held on May&amp;#160;20, 2009, our shareholders approved the Kraft
Foods Inc. Amended and Restated 2005 Performance Incentive Plan.
The amended plan includes, among other provisions, a limit on the
number of shares that may be granted under the plan, vesting
restrictions and a prohibition on stock option repricing. Under the
amended plan, we are authorized to issue a maximum of
168.0&amp;#160;million shares of our Common Stock. As of the effective
date of the amendment, there were 92.1 million shares available to
be granted under the plan, of which no more than 27.5&amp;#160;million
shares may be awarded as restricted or deferred stock.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In January 2009, we granted
1.4&amp;#160;million shares of stock in connection with our long-term
incentive plan. The market value per share was $27.00 on the date
of grant. The unvested shares have no voting rights and do not pay
dividends.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In February 2009, as part of our annual
incentive program, we issued 4.1&amp;#160;million shares of restricted
and deferred stock to eligible U.S. and non-U.S. employees. The
market value per restricted or deferred share was $23.64 on the
date of grant. Also, as part of our annual incentive program, we
granted 16.3&amp;#160;million stock options to eligible U.S. and
non-U.S. employees at an exercise price of $23.64.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We also issued 0.2&amp;#160;million
off-cycle shares of restricted and deferred stock during the first
six months of 2009. The weighted-average market value per
restricted or deferred share was $24.90 on the date of grant. In
aggregate, we issued 5.7&amp;#160;million restricted and deferred
shares during the first six months of 2009, including those issued
as part of our long-term incentive plan.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 1px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;During the first six months of 2009,
5.2&amp;#160;million shares of restricted and deferred stock vested at
a market value of $130 million. There were 3.0&amp;#160;million stock
options exercised during the first six months of 2009 with a total
intrinsic value of $32 million.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;!-- 6 Last_Row * DO NOT REMOVE OR EDIT --&gt;&lt;/tbody&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;

Plans:

held on May&amp;#160;20, 2009, our shareholders approved the Kraft
Foods Inc. Amended</NonNumericTextHeader>

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Pension Plans&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Components of Net Periodic Pension
Cost:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Net periodic pension cost consisted of
the following for the three and six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2009
and 2008:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;The following costs are included in
settlement losses above. Severance benefits from our cost-savings
initiatives and retiring employees who elected lump-sum payments
resulted in settlement losses for our U.S. plans of $40 million for
the three months and $66 million for the six months ended
June&amp;#160;30, 2009, and $13 million for the three months and $21
million for the six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2008.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Employer
Contributions:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We make contributions to our U.S. and
non-U.S. pension plans, primarily to the extent that they are tax
deductible and do not generate an excise tax liability. During the
first six months of 2009, we contributed $219 million to our U.S.
plans (including the $200 million contribution we made on May 1,
2009) and $86 million to our non-U.S. plans. Based on current tax
law, we plan to make further contributions of approximately $20
million to our U.S. plans and approximately $80 million to our
non-U.S. plans during the remainder of 2009. However, our actual
contributions may differ due to many factors, including changes in
tax and other benefit laws, or significant differences between
expected and actual pension asset performance or interest
rates.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font size=
"1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Postretirement Benefit
Plans&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Net postretirement health care costs
consisted of the following for the three and six months ended
June&amp;#160;30, 2009 and 2008:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Postemployment Benefit
Plans&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Net postemployment costs consisted of
the following for the three and six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2009
and 2008:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;td valign="bottom" colspan="18"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;The following costs are included in
other (credits) / costs above. We incurred $25 million in severance
charges in the second quarter of 2009 related to our Kraft Foods
Europe Reorganization. We also reversed $32 million in severance
charges in the second quarter of 2009 related to our Restructuring
Program as we sold a plant in Spain that we previously announced
for closure under the program. Additionally, the postemployment
cost of workforce reduction initiatives announced under the
Restructuring Program was $64 million during the three months and
$123 million during the six months ended June&amp;#160;30,
2008.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font size=
"1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We include the fair value of our asset
derivatives within other current assets and the fair value of our
liability derivatives within other current liabilities.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;The fair values (asset / (liability)) of
our derivative instruments at June&amp;#160;30, 2009 were determined
using:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center"
border="0"&gt;&lt;!-- 5 First_Row * DO NOT REMOVE OR EDIT --&gt;
&lt;tbody&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td width="6%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="6%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td width="53%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" width="6%"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1px solid" valign="bottom" align=
"middle" colspan="2"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Total&amp;#160;Fair&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;br /&gt;

Value&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1px solid" valign="bottom" align=
"middle" colspan="2"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;Quoted&amp;#160;Prices&amp;#160;in&amp;#160;&lt;br /&gt;
Active&amp;#160;Markets&lt;br /&gt;
for Identical&lt;br /&gt;
Assets&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;

"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Cash flow hedges affected accumulated
other comprehensive losses, net of income taxes, as
follows:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;td valign="top" colspan="18"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We record both (i)&amp;#160;the gain or loss
reclassified from AOCI into earnings and (ii)&amp;#160;the gain or loss
on ineffectiveness in:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style=
"MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; MARGIN-LEFT: 4em; TEXT-INDENT: -1.5em"&gt;
&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#8226;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;cost of sales for
commodity contracts;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style=
"MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; MARGIN-LEFT: 4em; TEXT-INDENT: -1.5em"&gt;
&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#8226;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;cost of sales or
marketing, administration and research costs for foreign exchange
contracts related to forecasted transactions, depending on the type
of transaction; and&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style=
"MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; MARGIN-LEFT: 4em; TEXT-INDENT: -1.5em"&gt;
&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#8226;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;interest and other
expense, net for foreign exchange contracts related to intercompany
loans and interest rate contracts.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We expect to transfer unrealized losses
of $31 million (net of taxes) for commodity cash flow hedges and
unrealized gains of $26 million (net of taxes) for foreign currency
cash flow hedges to earnings during the next 12 months. As of
June&amp;#160;30, 2009, we had hedged forecasted:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style=
"MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; MARGIN-LEFT: 4em; TEXT-INDENT: -1.5em"&gt;
&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#8226;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;commodity
transactions for periods not exceeding the next 18
months;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style=
"MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; MARGIN-LEFT: 4em; TEXT-INDENT: -1.5em"&gt;
&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#8226;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;interest rate
transactions for periods not exceeding the next 148 months;
and&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style=
"MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; MARGIN-LEFT: 4em; TEXT-INDENT: -1.5em"&gt;
&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;&amp;#8226;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;foreign currency
transactions for periods not exceeding the next 30 months, and
excluding intercompany loans, we had hedged forecasted foreign
currency transactions for periods not exceeding the next 12
months.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Fair Value Hedges:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;The effect of fair value hedges for the
three and six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2009 was (in
millions):&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" align="right"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;(1&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;)&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman" size=
"2"&gt;$&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom" align="right"&gt;&lt;font face="Times New Roman"
size="2"&gt;1&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" colspan="18"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We include the gain or loss on hedged
long-term debt and the offsetting loss or gain on the related
interest rate swap in interest and other expense, net.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;

"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Hedges of Net Investments in Foreign

"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;The effect of hedges of net investments

June&amp;#160;30, 2009 was (in millions):&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;td valign="top" colspan="13"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We recognized net gains on commodity
contracts not designated as hedging instruments of approximately
$225 million during the three months and approximately $285 million
during the six months ended June&amp;#160;30, 2008, directly as a
component of cost of sales. See our Form 10-K for the year ended
December&amp;#160;31, 2008 for additional information on our purpose
for entering into derivatives not designated as hedging instruments
and our overall risk management strategies.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note 10.&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Commitments
and Contingencies:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Legal Proceedings:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We are involved, from time to time, in
legal proceedings, claims, and governmental inspections or
investigations, arising in the ordinary course of our business.
While we cannot predict with certainty the results of these
matters, we do not expect that the ultimate costs to resolve these
matters will have a material effect on our financial
results.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Third-Party
Guarantees:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font face=
"Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We have third-party guarantees because
of our construction activities. As part of those transactions, we
guarantee that third parties will make contractual payments or
achieve performance measures. At June&amp;#160;30, 2009, the carrying
amount of our third-party guarantees on our condensed consolidated
balance sheet and the maximum potential payment under these
guarantees was $30 million. Substantially all of these guarantees
expire at various times through 2018.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font size=
"1"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;

</NonNumbericText>
